title: How to Turn on Wireless Charging on iPhone in 4 Quick Steps

steps.title: Note this information about MagSafe charging.
steps.content: Note this information about MagSafe charging. MagSafe wireless chargers have built-in magnets that align with the MagSafe magnets in certain iPhone models. MagSafe chargers are typically compatible with Qi charging, meaning you can use them on iPhones without MagSafe as well. [1] X Research source The following iPhone models are MagSafe compatible: iPhone 14, iPhone 14 Pro, iPhone 13, iPhone 13 Pro, iPhone 12, and iPhone 12 Pro. Charging an iPhone without MagSafe on the MagSafe charger might lead to slower charging times compared to a normal Qi wireless charger. Make sure not to put items with magnetic strips or RFID chips between the iPhone and the MagSafe charger. The magnets can damage these items.

steps.title: Plug in your wireless charger.
steps.content: Plug in your wireless charger. Connect your wireless charger to either the power adaptor it came with, or one recommended in the manual. Then, plug the power adapter into a normal household AC power source. [2] X Research source iPhones are compatible with Qi-certified wireless chargers. Note that only iPhone 8 and later has wireless charging. Here are other iPhones with wireless charging: iPhone X, iPhone 11, iPhone SE 2nd/3rd generation, iPhone 12, iPhone 13, and iPhone 14.

steps.title: Put the wireless charger on a flat surface.
steps.content: Put the wireless charger on a flat surface. This will prevent the iPhone from sliding off while charging.

steps.title: Put your iPhone on the wireless charger.
steps.content: Put your iPhone on the wireless charger. Make sure the iPhone’s screen is facing up, away from the charger. Your iPhone should start charging after a couple seconds! Wireless charging will turn on automatically when you place your iPhone on the wireless charger. [3] X Research source Typically, the best charging location is in the center of the wireless charger. If you’re using a MagSafe charger with a MagSafe iPhone, the magnets in the iPhone will attach to the MagSafe charger to securely attach it. If you decide to switch back to wired charging, check out our guides for cleaning your Lightning port and cleaning your Lightning cable .

steps.title: Remove objects between the iPhone and the charger.
steps.content: Remove objects between the iPhone and the charger. There are a few common issues that can prevent wireless charging from working. Since wireless charging uses magnetic induction, any objects between your iPhone and the wireless charger can inhibit charging. [4] X Research source Additionally, the magnetic induction can potentially damage magnetic strips and RFID chips. Remove any objects with these from your iPhone before using wireless charging. Even the case on your iPhone can prevent charging! Try removing it and trying to charge again.

steps.title: Turn off vibration.
steps.content: Turn off vibration. Your iPhone might move when it vibrates during a notification or phone call. This can displace the iPhone enough that it stops charging, even if it’s still on the charging pad.

steps.title: Unplug your iPhone.
steps.content: Unplug your iPhone. Your iPhone won’t wirelessly charge when connected to USB. [5] X Research source If you switch back to USB charging, see our guide for tips on charging your iPhone .
